Simpson","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"body":"h1. Getting started 

h2. Starting with the tests passing

h3. Questions

# _Do you think it would always be appropriate to just copy the "Expected" value reported by the test runner to make the tests pass? Why or why not?_
No, because the expected value could be wrong or not meet the program’s requirements.
# _What error do you get if you change the expectation to_ {{expect(actual === 'Hello, notworld!').toBeTruthy();}}_? Is this better or worse than the one you received earlier?_
- {{Error: expect(received).toBeTruthy()  Received: false}}
- Worse, because it doesn’t tell the tester why they received {{false}}, i.e., how the actual output string differs from the expected output string.

h2. How good is our test?

h3. Questions

# _Is the test_ [_a good one_|https://wiki.agiledigital.com.au/display/FORGE/Automated+Testing]_?_
Yes, but it only tests one input, so more tests are needed.
# _If you were inclined, how could you change your tests to detect that the implementation of the function had changed?_
Create another test with a different input value.

h1. Adding some more tests

h2. Copy Pasta 🍝

h3. Questions

# _When do you think it would be appropriate to copy-paste a test?_
When writing boilerplate or if you have forgotten the structure or syntax used by the testing framework.
# _Do you think that we should assess the ‘quality' of tests differently to how we assess the quality of the code under test?_
I think tests are often neglected and there is no reason that their quality should be less than the code under test. Especially because developers will inevitably read a codebase’s existing tests to guide them in writing more tests, so both bad and good test patterns would be replicated.
# _What are some methods that you can think of to discourage copy-pasting?_
- Linting rules which detect identical or near-identical code (the warnings should also explain why it is bad).
- Code reviews.

h2. Data-Driven testing

h3. Edge cases

h3. Questions

# _What edge cases can you think of for the code under test in this exercise?_
Empty string {{""}}, unicode characters, a long string, tabs, newlines.
# _Do you think that picking a language with a good type system reduces the number of edge cases we need to test?_
Yes, because I no longer need to create a test which, e.g., passes a {{number}} to a function which expects a {{string}}.

h3. Nicer reporting

# _Can you think of any drawbacks to using a data-provider?_
More complicated for newcomer, less readable, takes more time to create than copy-pasting.

h3. Reproduce the code under test

h3. Questions

# _Have you seen any other testing anti-patterns?_
Overly complex logic in tests, using loops instead of framework data provider such as {{test.each}}, too much variable assignment, not enough variable assignment (in-lining everything), low-value tests which only serve to increase coverage, tests which are very similar to each other, tests which don’t try hard to break the system (since the developer is emotionally invested in their work).
# _Can you think of how testing mig ht 'go wrong' when a bit of software has been around for a while? What do you think that the early warning signs of that failure may be?_
Tests start to fail unexpectedly after making changes to software? Or it becomes hard to debug why the old tests are failing?

h2. Data providers

h3. Questions

# _Do you think that having to create lots of instances of the same type in different parts of the system is a code smell? What could be done to address that problem rather than introduce data providers?_
Yes. Rewrite functions to only take the properties they require from that type? Consider whether those parts of the system belong together (e.g., two library files that contain similar functions)? Move the instances to a data file shared by the different parts of the system (or the testing modules which rely on them).
# _Do you think that parameterising a data provider (e.g. adding the name parameter above) is a good idea? What are some alternatives? How would you decide which one is appropriate?_
Yes, if they are reusable and get used. Property-based testing, creating data-providing functions, or creating a set of common test data in one file? It would depend how reusable the solution is (i.e., would it get used at all), and by how many lines of test code it would reduce the project (hundreds of lines less repetitive test code could make the next tester’s life easier), as well as how complicated it makes the tests?

h1. Testing a new function

h2. Questions

# _What other test cases can you think of?_
An array containing an untaxable and a taxable item, an array containing a taxable item where {{amountInCents}} is negative, an array containing a taxable item where {{amountInCents}} is 0, and an array containing a taxable item where {{amountInCents}} is a decimal number.
# _We haven't tested the case where there are multiple_ {{LineItems}} _in the array. Why do you think that code coverage is 100% when we haven't covered that case?_
Because testing a single {{LineItem}} is enough for all code paths to be hit.
# _Do you think that testing the case with multiple_ {{LineItems}} _is valuable? What parts of the implementation could break and not be detected by the current set of tests?_
Yes. If an array containing a taxable {{LineItem}} with a negative {{amountInCents}} and a taxable {{LineItem}} with a positive {{amountInCents}} is given as input, then the resulting total could be less than expected, zero (if {{abs(amountInCents1) = abs(amountInCents2)}}), or negative (if the negative {{amountInCents}}is bigger than the positive {{amountInCents}} ). However, we would expect the total tax of a list of taxable items (where {{amountInCents}} is nonzero) to always be positive. A possible fix could be to take the absolute value of {{amountInCents}}, or return an error if a negative {{amountInCents}} is ever provided (preferable, because it could tell us that another part of the program is broken, or that the user is providing bad input).

h2. More test cases

h3. Questions

# _Now that you have the complex case (with lots of_ {{LineItems}}_) do you think that it is still useful to retain the simpler cases?_
Yes, because, for example, the “multiple taxable items” case would pass and the “a taxable item“ case would fail when given {{[taxableItem, taxableItem]}} under the faulty reducer implementation, where {{taxableItem}} has been changed to:

{noformat}  const taxableItem: LineItem = {
    name: "Test Taxable Item",
    amountInCents: 199 * 2, // double what it was
    attractsSalesTax: true,
  };{noformat}
# _Would you prefer to see some of many small simple tests fail? Or one large test fail?_
Some of many small simple tests (easier to debug the cause because output would be more relevant to the failure).
# _We had to prefix_ {{acc}} _with_ {{_}} _so that we could run the tests? Why? Does this help us catch potential problems with an implementation before we even write a test?_
Because TypeScript will not transpile code containing functions with unused parameters (unless we explicitly add {{_}}). Yes, because the error serves as a reminder that a parameter is unused.

h2. A more complex function

h3. Questions

# _How many rows do you have in your test array now?_
9.
# _What interesting values did you think of for the tax rate?_
0, 1, 2, -1, -0.5, 0.5.

h2. Light refactoring

h3. Questions

# _Has the readability of the code under test been improved?_
Yes, although the function signature of {{totalSalesTax}} is now arguably harder to read from the perspective of someone who isn’t used to passing functions as arguments.
# _Are you more or less confident that you would pick up issues in the code as it changes over time?_
Yes, because if someone changes the implementation of {{salesTax}}, the {{totalSalesTax}} tests won’t fail because a specific sales tax implementation is hardcoded into the tests. But the {{salesTax}} tests will fail. This alerts us to focus our attention on the {{salesTax}} code. Similarly, if someone changes {{totalSalesTax}} and its tests start to fail but {{salesTax}}'s tests continue to pass, we know the problem must lie with {{totalSalesTax}} and not {{salesTax}}.
# _If there are future problems with the code do you think you would get good clues about the cause of problem from the tests?_
Yes, because the tests rely on less inputs, and the logic of calculating the sales tax has been decoupled from {{totalSalesTax}} (each function now does only one thing), allowing us to pinpoint the cause of the problem more easily.

h2. There has got to be a better way

h3. Questions

# _We talked about two properties of_ {{reverse}} _above. What property-based testing patterns are they examples of?_
- an invariant under transformation
- an invertible function
# _What are some properties of the_ {{helloWorld}} _function that you tested before?_
TODO:

h3. Questions

# _Does it look like fast-check did a good job simplifying the failed inputs in each case?_
TODO:
# _Does fast-check give you confidence that it could pick up errors in the same way that human-generated "interesting" values could?_
TODO:

h2. Implement more property-based tests

h3. Questions

# _What did you find the hardest part about writing property-based tests to be?_

Plan","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10034","from":null,"fromString":null,"to":"","toString":"Clone the tool from its repo.

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to read users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk [YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid [YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/ list-users
```

Using the same set of parameters list all the groups:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk [YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid [YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/ list-groups
```

Select one of the groups from the list, and retrieve it's ID

Attempt to list the users within the group:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk [YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid [YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/ list-users --group [GROUP ID]
```

Verify that you have successfully listed all non-deprovisioned users within the given group.

Attempt to manipulate the group in question, removing users, adding users, and test that the tool correctly updates. Test that running the list-users command with no group argument and with only the privilege of okta.users.read will work.

Try and list the users in an empty group and confirm that the computer both recognize that the group is empty, and exits without an error code.

Verify that the tool exits cleanly."},{"field":"status","fieldtype":"jira","fieldId":"status","from":"3","fromString":"In Progress","to":"10011","toString":"Waiting for Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10031","from":"","fromString":"h4. Why? (on)

There may be many situations in which an Okta administrator/developer may want to create a user but also perform some operation on them i.e. add them to a group.

h4. Improvement (i)

# Implement a feature that can allow an administrator to create a user and add them to an existing or new group in one command, under the {{create-group}} command.
# Implement a feature that can allow an administrator to create a user and update their details under the {{create-user}} command

h4. How? (/)

There are many potential solutions to tackle this problem:

# Allow for a manual command entry that can be streamlined using shell piping and filtering commands
# Reconfigure {{yargs}} to allow for additional entries pertaining to the creation of new users

This issue would be ongoing and scales with the amount of possible creation and manipulation options there exists in the {{oktagon}} module. Once this improvement has been made for all previous code, then it can be implemented as part of any future issues.

Not all improvements in this issue need to be made for it to be completed.","to":"","toString":"h4. Why? (on)

There may be many situations in which an Okta administrator/developer may want to create a user but also perform some operation on them i.e. add them to a group.

h4. Improvement (i)

# Implement a feature that can allow an administrator to create a user and add them to an existing or new group in one command, under the {{create-group}} or {{create-user}} commands.
# Implement a feature that can allow an administrator to create a user and update their details under the {{create-user}} or {{update-user}} commands.

h4. How? (/)

There are many potential solutions to tackle this problem:

# Allow for a manual command entry that can be streamlined using shell piping and filtering commands
# Reconfigure {{yargs}} to allow for additional entries pertaining to the creation of new users

This issue would be ongoing and scales with the amount of possible creation and manipulation options there exists in the {{oktagon}} module. Once this improvement has been made for all previous code, then it can be implemented as part of any future issues.

Not all improvements in this issue need to be made for it to be completed."}]},{"id":"40488","author":{"self":"https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/user?accountId=62fc2eb7d75f523a60edfa31","accountId":"62fc2eb7d75f523a60edfa31","emailAddress":"ohwalters@agiledigital.com.au","avatarUrls":{"48x48":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","24x24":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","16x16":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","32x32":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png"},"displayName":"Olivia Plan","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10034","from":null,"fromString":null,"to":"","toString":"Clone the tool from its repo.

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to read users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk [YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid [YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/ list-users
```

Using the same set of parameters list all the groups:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk [YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid [YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/ list-groups
```

Either create a new user or use an existing user for experimentation. Retrieve this user's ID from the user list. Retrieve the selected group's ID from the group list. Add the user to the group using the `add-user-to-group` command - it should work even if the user was already in the group.

Attempt to remove the user to the group:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk [YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid [YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/ remove-user-from-group --user [USER ID] --group [GROUP ID]
```

Verify that you have successfully added the user to the new group. Attempting to perform the same command will result in no errors and no change to the group or user structure.

Try and attempt to add multiple different users to the same group, and one user to multiple different groups. And attempt to remove that user from all of them. Confirm using the Okta software that all of these changes work. Attempt to input invalid IDs to confirm that the tool only works on existing groups and/or users.

Verify that the tool exits cleanly."},{"field":"status","fieldtype":"jira","fieldId":"status","from":"3","fromString":"In Progress","to":"10011","toString":"Waiting for Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10035","from":"","fromString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator I can add an existing user to an existing group when I’m testing Okta configuration and integrations so that I can quickly and easily set up test users.

h4. Experience (i)

An Okta administrator enters a command like:

{noformat}oktagon add-user-to-group --user-id [XXXX] --group [YYYY]{noformat}

and receives feedback as to whether the user was added to the group or not.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an Okta administrator I am now able to:

# add users to groups.

 

h4. Constraints (!)

* Each rule or restriction that must be adhered to by the system.","to":"","toString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator, I can remove an existing user from a group when I’m testing Okta configuration and integrations so that I can quickly and easily set up test users.

h4. Experience (i)

An Okta administrator enters a command like:

{noformat}oktagon remove-user-from-group --user-id [XXXX] --group [YYYY]{noformat}

and receives feedback as to whether the user was removed from the group or not.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an Okta administrator I am now able to:

# remove users to groups.

h4. Constraints (!)

* Each rule or restriction that must be adhered to by the system."}]},{"id":"40324","author":{"self":"https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/user?accountId=557058%3Ab6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723","accountId":"557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723","emailAddress":"dxspasojevic@agiledigital.com.au","avatarUrls":{"48x48":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/48","24x24":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/24","16x16":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/16","32x32":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/32"},"displayName":"Daniel Thomas","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"body":"If the remove-user-from-group function is provided a valid user and a valid group it always returns “Removed user \[<userid>] from group \[<groupid>].”. I would have expected a different message if the user was not in the group to begin with.

All other combinations of inputs behaved as I expected and it does remove people from the group if they are a member.

I can imagine having a different message if the user wasn’t already in the group could require a separate API call, and maybe even separate scopes granted for the application. If that is the case then it’s not worth changing I don’t think. Walters","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"body":"[~accountid:624a68cef3824d006a5aa484] About your comment on the removal of a user that is not in the group - the Okta API does not actually have a method of checking if a user is in a group outside of manually having to search through the entire list of users in that group. So for large groups, it could make the removal very slow. There is in fact no separate API call at all.

Okta’s API also throws no errors if you try to remove a user from a group they don’t exist in. So essentially it’s going add too much temporal complexity to the code in order to check something that doesn’t necessarily break anything - it’s mainly just a user feedback issue.

This same situation appears in add-user-to-group as ./dist/oktagon --pk \[YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Using the same set of parameters list all the groups:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk \[YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-groups
```

In order to confirm sub-task [https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/browse/IE-25|https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/browse/IE-25|smart-link], please ensure that the listed groups match that of the groups specified within the organisation.

Either create a new user or use an existing user for experimentation. Retrieve this user's ID from the user list. Retrieve the selected group's ID from the group list. Confirm that the user does not currently exist in said group.

Attempt to add the user to the group:
```
./dist/oktagon --pk \[YOUR PRIVATE KEY]  --cid \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] add-user-to-group --user \[USER ID] --group \[GROUP ID]
```

Verify that you have successfully added the user to the new group. Attempting to perform the same command will result in the user being re-added to the group.

Try and attempt to add multiple different users to the same group, and one user to multiple different groups. Attempt to input invalid IDs to confirm that the tool only works on existing groups and/or users.

Walters","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"body":"The steps in order to create a production/sandbox environment for okta testing is as follows:
1. Sign up to Okta to create a new developer domain, you should get a URL along the lines of {{https://dev-[id]-admin.okta.com}}

2. Add a series of test users with test emails. Automatically set the user’s passwords to force activate them

3. Create a web application with the Okta API setting selected.

4. Allow access to the needed Okta API Scopes, and set the web application to use public/private key pairs

5. When running Oktagon, use an Org. URL of Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10035","from":null,"fromString":null,"to":"","toString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator, I activate a user with a {{DEPROVISIONED}} or {{STAGED}} status.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice is reconfiguring Okta and decides to deactivate a user. However she made a mistake and accidentally deactivated the wrong user.

In order to rectify her mistake, Alice enters into the terminal:

{noformat}oktagon activate-user --email bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au{noformat}

Alice gets confirmation that the user has been reactivated with a {{ACTIVE}} status.

When she uses those credentials to authenticate to Okta, she is _not_ prompted to set a new password.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an okta administrator I am now able to:

# Activate an already existing user with a {{DEPROVISIONED}} or {{STAGED}} status
# Authenticate the user without entering a password



h4. Constraints (!)

* Alice should not have to click any links in emails to activate the user.
* Alice should not have to set a new password when using those credentials."}]},{"id":"40047","author":{"self":"https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/user?accountId=62fc2eb7d75f523a60edfa31","accountId":"62fc2eb7d75f523a60edfa31","emailAddress":"ohwalters@agiledigital.com.au","avatarUrls":{"48x48":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","24x24":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","16x16":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","32x32":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png"},"displayName":"Olivia Walters","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"created":"2022-09-05T13:20:54.408+1000","items":[{"field":"Improvement Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10031","from":"","fromString":"h4. Why? (on)

As an Okta administrator, I can reactivate a deactivated user i.e. alter a user with a {{DEPROVISIONED}} or {{STAGED}} status to {{ACTIVE}}.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice enters in an argument for the {{oktagon deactivate-user}} command. However she accidentally entered the ID of the wrong user.

To rectify her mistake, Alice runs the command:

{noformat}oktagon activate-user --email bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au{noformat}

She is not prompted to create a new password for this user, but instead can see the password of the activated user if one existed prior to deactivation.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an Okta administrator, I am now able to:

# Activate a user that is currently staged or deprovisioned
# Activate a user without setting a new password for said Plan","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10034","from":"","fromString":"Clone the tool from [its repo|https://github.com/agiledigital-labs/oktagon].

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Come up with a testing email address which does not belong to an existing user.

Try to create a new user with a name and email

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] create-user --email \[USER EMAIL] --fname \[USER FIRST NAME] --lname \[USER LAST NAME]
```

Verify that you have successfully created a new user with an active status and a provided password, save the provided password. Then try and run the exact same command again, and confirm that it fails as the user now already exists.

Go to the organisation’s web page and attempt to sign in with the created user credentials (email and auto-generated password). Confirm that you can access the web page without any need to reset passwords. Check as well that no activation email was sent to the linked account.

Verify that the tool exits cleanly.","to":"","toString":"Clone the tool from [its repo|https://github.com/agiledigital-labs/oktagon].

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Come up with a testing email address which does not belong to an existing user.

Try to create a new user with a name and email

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] create-user --email \[USER EMAIL] --fname \[USER FIRST NAME] --lname \[USER LAST NAME]
```

Verify that you have successfully created a new user with an active status and a provided password, save the provided password. Then try and run the exact same command again, and confirm that it fails as the user now already exists.

Go to the organisation’s web page and attempt to sign in with the created user credentials (email and auto-generated password). Confirm that you can access the web page without any need to reset passwords. Check as well that no activation email was sent to the linked account.

Verify that the tool exits Observing the code in order to determine if decisions made when implementing were proper, and if modifications need to be made to more closely align the code with a desired design philosophy.","to":"","toString":"Clone the tool from [its repo|https://github.com/agiledigital-labs/oktagon].

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Come up with a testing email address which does not belong to an existing user.

Try to create a new user with a name and email

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] create-user --email \[USER EMAIL] --fname \[USER FIRST NAME] --lname \[USER LAST NAME]

Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10035","from":null,"fromString":null,"to":"","toString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator, I can create a new user when I am iterating on configuration or development so that I can quickly test changes.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice is reconfiguring Okta and needs a user to validate some changes, she enters the shell command:

{noformat}oktagon create-user --email bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au{noformat}

and see output informing her that bob has been created, activated and a password has been allocated. She sees the password in the output of the command.

When she uses those credentials to authenticate to Okta, she is _not_ prompted to set a new password. 

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an okta administrator I am now able to:

# create a new user.
# authenticate as that user without setting a new password.

 

h4. Constraints (!)

* Alice should not have to click any links in emails to activate the user.
* Alice should not have to set a new password when using those credentials."}]},{"id":"39150","author":{"self":"https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/user?accountId=557058%3Ab6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723","accountId":"557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723","emailAddress":"dxspasojevic@agiledigital.com.au","avatarUrls":{"48x48":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/48","24x24":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/24","16x16":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/16","32x32":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/32"},"displayName":"Daniel Spasojevic","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"created":"2022-08-22T10:04:08.550+1000","items":[{"field":"Improvement Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10031","from":"","fromString":"h4. Plan","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10034","from":"","fromString":"Clone the tool from [its repo|https://github.com/agiledigital-labs/oktagon].

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Pick a user to delete (if you don't already have a suitable test user, you should create one via the Okta admin portal).

Try to delete the user (WARNING: this is not reversible):

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] delete-user \[USER ID]
```

Verify that you get an error because the user hasn’t been de-activated yet.

De-activate the user:

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] deactivate-user \[USER ID]
```

Then delete the user (WARNING: this is not reversible):

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] delete-user \[USER ID]
```

Verify that the tool exits cleanly.

Verify that the user is no longer visible when listing users.

Verify that when you try to delete the user again that you get a (reasonable) error message.

Verify that when you try to delete a non-existent user that you get a (reasonable) error message.","to":"","toString":"Clone the tool from [its repo|https://github.com/agiledigital-labs/oktagon].

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Pick a user to delete (if you don't already have a suitable test user, you should create one via the Okta admin portal).

Try to delete the user (WARNING: this is not reversible):

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] delete-user \[USER ID]
```

Verify that you get an error because the user hasn’t been de-activated yet.

De-activate the user:

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] deactivate-user \[USER ID]
```

Then delete the user (WARNING: this is not reversible):

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] delete-user \[USER ID]
```

Verify that the tool exits cleanly.

Verify that the user is no longer visible when listing users.

Verify that when you try to delete the user again that you get a (reasonable) error message.

Plan","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10034","from":null,"fromString":null,"to":"","toString":"Clone the tool from [its repo|https://github.com/agiledigital-labs/oktagon].

Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Pick a user to delete (if you don't already have a suitable test user, you should create one via the Okta admin portal).

Try to delete the user (WARNING: this is not reversible):

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] delete-user \[USER ID]
```

Verify that you get an error because the user hasn’t been de-activated yet.

De-activate the user:

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] deactivate-user \[USER ID]
```

Then delete the user (WARNING: this is not reversible):

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] delete-user \[USER ID]
```

Verify that the tool exits cleanly.

Verify that the user is no longer visible when listing users.

Verify that when you try to delete the user again that you get a (reasonable) error message.

Verify that when you try to delete a non-existent user that you get a (reasonable) error message."}]},{"id":"39311","author":{"self":"https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/user?accountId=62fc2eb7d75f523a60edfa31","accountId":"62fc2eb7d75f523a60edfa31","emailAddress":"ohwalters@agiledigital.com.au","avatarUrls":{"48x48":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","24x24":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","16x16":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png","32x32":"https://secure.gravatar.com/avatar/654c02678188982469f1e0031c4d6c51?d=https%3A%2F%2Favatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net%2Finitials%2FOW-2.png"},"displayName":"Olivia Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator, I can deactivate an active user when I am iterating on configuration or development so that I can clean up after myself.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice uses her terminal to list all the users. She sees that one of her test users ([bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au|mailto:bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au]) is still listed and active. She then issues another command:

{noformat}oktagon deactivate-user bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au{noformat}

and see output informing her of {{bob's}} new status.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an okta administrator I am now able to:

# de-activate okta users.

 

h4. Constraints (!)

* ","to":"","toString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator, I can delete a deactivated user when I am iterating on configuration or development so that I can clean up after myself.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice uses her terminal to list all the users. She sees that one of her test users ([bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au|mailto:bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au]) is still listed. She then issues another command:

{noformat}oktagon delete-user bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au{noformat}

and see output informing her of {{bob's}} new status.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an okta administrator I am now able to:

# delete deactivated okta users.

h4. Constraints (!)

* Only _deactivated_ users should be Using a private key and client id for an application that has privileges to *read* users, list all the users:
```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] list-users
```

Pick a user to de-activate (if you don't already have a suitable test user, you should create one via the Okta admin portal).

De-activate the user:

```
./dist/oktagon --client-id \[YOUR CLIENT ID] --ou [https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/|https://live-nonprod-esgtech-co.oktapreview.com/] deactivate-user \[USER ID]
```

Validate that you see an informative message and that the tool exits cleanly.

Pick a user to de-activate (if you don't already have a test user, you should create one via the Okta admin portal).

```

```

Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator, I can deactivate an active user when I am iterating on configuration or development so that I can clean up after myself.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice uses her terminal to list all the users. She sees that one of her test users ([bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au|mailto:bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au]) is still listed and active. She then issues another command:

{noformat}oktagon deactivate-user bob+testing@agiledigital.com.au{noformat}

and see output informing her of {{bob's}} new status.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an okta administrator I am now able to:

# de-activate okta users.

 

h4. Constraints (!)

Description","fieldtype":"custom","fieldId":"customfield_10035","from":"","fromString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator I can use a command line to list users when I am managing users so that I can quickly see what users exist in an account.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice uses her terminal to invoke a command line tool 

{noformat}octagon list-users{noformat}

to quickly see the {{login}} {{email}} {{displayName}} and {{status}} of all users.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an Okta adminstrator I am now able to:

# List users
# See their key details

h4. Constraints (!)

* We will use private key authentication for this tool. The private key and other sensitive information should be sourced from the environment, not hardcoded or passed as command line arguments.","to":"","toString":"h4. Summary (on)

As an Okta administrator I can use a command line to list users when I am managing users so that I can quickly see what users exist in an account.

h4. Experience (i)

Alice uses her terminal to invoke a command line tool 

{noformat}oktagon list-users{noformat}

to quickly see the {{login}} {{email}} {{displayName}} and {{status}} of all users.

h4. Acceptance Criteria (/)

As an Okta adminstrator I am now able to:

# List users
# See their key details

h4. Constraints (!)

Why? (on) 

jiralint currently only support on-prem Jira ("Jira Server"). We want to continue to benefit from it as we migrate to Jira Cloud.

h4. Improvement ✅ 

# Support Jira Cloud in jiralint.

h4. How? 

# See [https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint/issues/158|https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint/issues/158|smart-link] 
# Ensure you can build locally following [https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#build|https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#build|smart-link] 
# Get access to our on-prem Jira instance and ensure you can authenticate following [https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#jira-authentication|https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#jira-authentication|smart-link] 
# Ensure you can run jiralint.
# Inspect the output and poke around in the codebase to become familiar.
# Take the Jira Cloud authentication code from [https://github.com/agiledigital/data-platform|https://github.com/agiledigital/data-platform|smart-link]  and update jiralint to be able to talk to Jira Cloud","to":"","toString":"h4. Why? (on)

# Ensure you can run jiralint.

Why? (on) 

jiralint currently only support on-prem Jira ("Jira Server"). We want to continue to benefit from it as we migrate to Jira Cloud.

h4. Improvement ✅ 

# Support Jira Cloud in jiralint.

h4. How? 

# See [https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint/issues/158|https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint/issues/158|smart-link] 
# Ensure you can build locally following [https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#build|https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#build|smart-link] 
# Get access to our on-prem Jira instance and ensure you can authenticate following [https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#jira-authentication|https://github.com/agiledigital/jiralint#jira-authentication|smart-link] 
# Ensure you can run jiralint.
# Inspect the output and poke around in the codebase to become familiar.
# Take the Jira Cloud authentication code from [https://github.com/agiledigital/data-platform|https://github.com/agiledigital/data-platform|smart-link]  and update jiralint to be able to talk to Jira Cloud"}]},{"id":"38661","author":{"self":"https://agiledigital.atlassian.net/rest/api/2/user?accountId=557058%3Ab6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723","accountId":"557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723","emailAddress":"dxspasojevic@agiledigital.com.au","avatarUrls":{"48x48":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/48","24x24":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/24","16x16":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/16","32x32":"https://avatar-management--avatars.us-west-2.prod.public.atl-paas.net/557058:b6727a96-cf4a-4599-a218-072e69737723/d77e5ee4-6216-405e-9228-61b39e42d14f/32"},"displayName":"Daniel Spasojevic","active":true,"timeZone":"Australia/Sydney","accountType":"atlassian"},"created":"2022-08-10T10:26:26.468+1000","items":[{"field":"description","fieldtype":"jira","fieldId":"description","from":null,"fromString":"h4. h4. Improvement (i)
